The following excerpt from a caption for the picture originally published in Alexander Gardner’s Photographic Sketch Book of the War describes a “sad scene” in language that would have resonated with contemporary readers. “It speaks ill of the residents of that part of Virginia, that they allowed even the remains of those they considered enemies, to decay unnoticed where they fell. The soldiers, to whom commonly falls the task of burying the dead, may possibly have been called away before the task was completed. At such times the native dwellers of the neighborhood would usually come forward and provide sepulture for such as had been left uncovered.”93 The photograph exemplifies the limits of photography during the Civil War. Rather than depicting battles as they unfolded, Gardner, O’Sullivan, Brady, and others often had to content themselves with scenes of postbattle carnage—shocking, but literally and figuratively lifeless.

On a denotative, or descriptive, level we see a foreground that depicts the results of war: death, a stretcher (noting the handles on either side) on which rests broken bodies and the skulls of five men (with a sixth lying on the ground), and a seated African American man who might have been operating the stretcher. The body parts and skulls are rather haphazardly arranged, as if the men simply tossed them on the cart with little regard or ceremony. They may be Confederate soldier remains—former slave owners, perhaps, fighting to keep that institution alive. Thus, we might sympathize with these men and their profane treatment of these remains. We see a single disembodied boot lying in front of the stretcher. The five skulls atop the pile look as though they were placed purposely and possibly to keep a count of the number of bodies unearthed. With almost Hamlet-like similarity, the skull on the far left gazes out at the viewer along with the seated man—the man expressionless, the skull seemingly smiling at us. Although slightly angled downward from left to right, the composition of the photograph is balanced. In the background, four men, tools in hand, dig into the earth to recover more bodies and body parts.

On the symbolic or connotative level, we have the African Americans, possibly former slaves, performing the grim and thankless task of cleaning up the battlefield. In many ways, they are as dead as the remains they gather, their futures unclear, their lives as torn as the bodies on the stretcher. This image symbolically depicts a Holocaust—an American Holocaust—and like the Holocaust imagery from a later war, it documents the tragedy of war’s reality. Indeed, death and photography are intricately intertwined. Images of death, in many ways, took center stage in the photographic work coming out of the Civil War. We find this difficult to understand today, in part because modern governments have tried to suppress the dissemination of images of death to maintain control of public perception and maintain home-front morale. More generally, in addition, photographing bodies grew common later in the nineteenth century. To create a keepsake, Americans of the time often hired photographers to take pictures of a dead relative, sometimes surrounded by family members.94

Today, by contrast, the practice is simply not acceptable in most cases, although the decentralized nature of the Internet—as well as some other media forms such as documentary film and surveillance video—have provided images of death and destruction that occasionally leak through controlling agents and agencies to shock the public. The practice of photographing the dead reflects an era’s familiarity with death, writes cultural historian Nicholas Mirzoeff. Photography’s beginnings came at a time of “profound social change in attitudes to the dead and to death. It thus participated in a new means of configuring death at the same time that it offered an everyday reminder of death.”95 Mirzoeff concludes that death was simply part of nineteenth-century everyday life in a way that is difficult for those of us in the modern West to imagine. Death did not take place so much in hospitals as it did in the home. Infant mortality rates were high, diseases easily cured today killed people in the prime of life, and surgical tools and techniques that today save the lives of victims of traumatic accidents and wartime wounds simply did not exist. As former slaves, the men in Figure 13 were probably well acquainted with death in its many forms.

At almost the other extreme—in both the medium and the message—Figure 14 depicts a sense of profound optimism, one afforded by the same forms of technological innovation that also helped create the weapons of destruction used in the Civil War. The artist of “The Progress of the Century,” an 1876 Currier and Ives lithograph, depicts the technological innovations that influenced both the course of the Civil War and the development of the nineteenth-century press—with a man using the telegraph in the foreground, and a steam press, a steamboat, and a locomotive featured behind.

caption.p: “The Progress of the Century—The Lightning Steam Press, the Electric Telegraph, the Locomotive, [and] the Steamboat,” Currier and Ives lithograph, 1876, Library of Congress, accessed May 15, 2012, http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/90716345.

sec.p: Although the “progress” depicted in the lithograph coincided with the terrible bloodshed of the Civil War, many Americans at the time believed that the Union victory made possible the continued advances in communications and transportation throughout the remainder of the century. The artist even invokes divine will as part of technological innovation, as evidenced by the telegraphic message sprawling to the floor: “Liberty and Union now and forever one and inseparable. Glory to God in the highest. On earth, peace, good will toward men.”

Nevertheless, important continuities exist. The sensational images of the Civil War, the Reconstruction, and the Gilded Age helped lay the groundwork for illustrated, photographic, and even color visual materials during the era of yellow journalism, as well as the sensational tabloids of the 1920s. As Tebbel and Zuckerman have noted, “Frank Leslie’s various illustrated papers had pictured society, scandal, civic problems, politics, and a variety of other matters in essentially the same way the tabloids and their supplements were doing half a century or more later. The difference, of course, was photography and the technology of reproducing pictures.”96 The technology changed, yet the nature of the depictions remained the same.

While the images studied in this monograph can gauge to some extent both the interests of readers and the trends in publishing at the time, the overall effect of these images should not be overstated. Just as with other forms of communication, an image can have myriad effects, some of which may include its ability to inform viewers, or serve a cathartic function, or to evoke, as Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Robert K. Merton suggested in terms more theoretical, an action-numbing effect similar to the narcotizing dysfunction.97 Although images can clearly influence the understanding of events—both among contemporary viewers and among subsequent generations—broader social forces can overwhelm the impact of even the most potent images, leaving conclusions about their overall meaning the subject of continued historical inquiry.

Indeed, early photographers themselves pointed to these choices in defending their work as a new art form rather than as mere visual stenography.98 In 1851, the first issue of the Photographic Art-Journal praised Brady for “elevating [the daguerreotype] into the dignity and beauty of an art of taste.”99 The pictorial record initiated during the Civil War, as declared by Henry Wysham Lanier in 1911, was “indisputably authentic, vividly illuminating, and the final evidence in any question of detail.”100

Regardless, photographs at best reflect one reality, often an incomplete one. Stated plainly, a photograph can be faked. A scene can be rearranged, as Brady was accused of doing in some of his pictures. Or a greater fraud can be perpetrated, as William H. Mumler notoriously did with his double-exposure “spirit photographs” in the years after the Civil War.101 Even in the absence of staging and trick photography, a photograph reflects choices made by its creator, including choices of perspective, distance, and exposure time.

In sum, Americans of the nineteenth century had read about General Burnside, but for most of them, it took Brady’s portrait to put a face to him and make his persona at least in part a visual reality. In addition, many contemporary viewers approached the images with experiences that we lack. To take the most obvious case, we know how the Civil War ended; they did not. And while they did not know the trajectory of the rest of the nineteenth century, we can in hindsight assess what newspaper audiences found to be both shocking and entertaining.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Gregory A. Borchard is an associate in the Hank Greenspun School of Journalism and Media Studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV). His research has focused on the nineteenth century press and includes Abraham Lincoln and Horace Greeley, a book published by Southern Illinois University Press (2011), and the co-authored book Journalism in the Civil War Era for Peter Lang (2010). He teaches classes in journalism history, reporting, and research methods.

Lawrence J. Mullen is a professor in the Hank Greenspun School of Journalism and Media Studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV). His research and teaching interests include the study of visual aesthetics, and media and community. His publications have explored the phenomenon of visual communication in several settings including the nexus between community and visuality. His courses feature the subjects of visual studies, research methods, social media, games, and virtual environments.

Stephen Bates is an associate professor in the Hank Greenspun School of Journalism and Media Studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV). He is the author, coauthor, or editor of four books. He has been a fellow of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and the Joan Shorenstein Center for the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. He teaches First Amendment law and political communication courses.
